tripreview.Title: "Historical connection"
tripreview.sentence: Do spare 1-2 hour from your schedule to have feel of historical connection of Kocchi.
The Jew street is an attraction not only for the handicraft items but also give you a feeling that you are walking through a historical lane.

tripreview.Title: "Old dutch palace"
tripreview.sentence: A walk is recommended.
Its about 2-4 kilometer from Fort Kochi.
a walk will show you a daily life of the Kochi people.
Weaving through streets crowded, shops, eateries etc.

tripreview.Title: "Mattancherry a must"
tripreview.sentence: In the heart of the old part of Cochin.
Hotels here can be a little cheaper and lots of homestays available.
Close to lots of things to see and some reasonable shopping.

tripreview.Title: "Nothing much to do except jetty"
tripreview.sentence: They have a lot of antique shops.
We found the biggest vaarppu in the world in one of the shops.
But they are all expensive and couldn't afford to buy in our budget trip.
The jetty service was not available in the afternoon time.
There is a dutch palace, dutch cemetry and synagogue which were closed since we went on a Friday afternoon.
But the roads are clean and neat and it was nice to work through them just watching the shops.

tripreview.Title: "town with buildings of the colonial era pointing to a vibrant past"
tripreview.sentence: Mattancherry, once a active centre of trade, particularly in spices after the invasions from across the sea changed a lot but still the buildings of the colonial era, mosques, churches, agraharams and the Jewish synagogue exist.

The main attractions of Mattancherry are the Dutch Palace, Paradesi Synagogue, Jain Temple, Spice market, Jewish Cemetery, Clock tower, Jewish town and apart from these a number of food outlets and antique shops are there.
The Paradesi Synagogue more than a hundred years old houses many rare antique objects that add to the grandeur of the place.
The light falling through the large open windows make the sight of chandeliers and lamps more delightful.
Next to the Paradesi synagogue is an imposing clock tower which was constructed in 1760, about 45 feet long, has four faces with numerals in Latin, Hebrew and Malayalam.
One side is blank.
The dial facing the Maharajas face has Malayalam numerals, the one facing the synagogue, Hebrew and the third one, Roman.
Jew Town is the narrow street between Mattancherry Palace and the Pardesi Synagogue.
It is famous for the antique shops all along its sides.
The colonial buildings lining the street add to its old-world charm.

Though Jew Town has lost much of its earlier glory but it has retained its status as an important centre of spice trade and when we pass through the area we can experience the exotic odor of the finest ginger, cloves, cardamom, turmeric and pepper, also known as black gold, emanate from the spice warehouses lining the street.
The Jewish Cemetery, with tomb stones inscribed in Malayalam and Hebrew, is at one end of Jew Street.
Jain Temple inspired by the Gujarat temples is another religious institution of Mattancherry.
Built in 1960, the temple complex is sprawled over a large area with various blocks constructed for prayers and as places for offerings.

The Dutch Palace built in a Hindu Temple style has a large collection of mural paintings and apart from these, there are exhibits of Dutch maps of old Kochi, royal palanquins with floral designs, silver sequined gowns, royal umbrellas make of silk and brass, the ceremonial royal sword and other royal paraphernalia on display in different rooms of the palace.
Though I have been to Mattancherry several times, I visited Mattancherry with my friend who came down from Chennai and we spend a whole day exploring the town.
The small restaurants serve tasty and fresh Indian and Chinese cuisines and apart from these we saw several sweet shops too.

tripreview.Title: "Nice Museum at this place."
tripreview.sentence: A good museum with lots of information on the Rajas of Kochi.
A good place to visit.
One can visualize the lifestyle of the Kings who ruled Kochi, their relationships with Portugese, Dutch and British, the customs and the Kingdom etc.

tripreview.Title: "Combination of so many things"
tripreview.sentence: Mattancherry is an area of Old kochi or fort kochi which can be either accessed by road from Kochi or by jetty.
Many small shops are there for your shopping needs.
Apart from these we will find tourist destination like dutch palace, museum, synagogue etc in this area.

tripreview.Title: "Typical Shopping area"
tripreview.sentence: Nothing great about this place.
Merely a shopping destination.
Passed by this place en route Jewish Synagogue.

tripreview.Title: "'Realising old times'"
tripreview.sentence: Matancherry is basically old Kochi, all the historical places to visit are based in Matancherry only.
By road it is almost 1 hr ride.
But there is boat service from Kochi to Matancherry and it takes only 35 min.

Instead of doing Kochi sightseeing with any tour operator, it is better to come matancherry in morning and spend a whole day here going to places like churches, dutch palace, the jew town and the ever famous chinese fishing nets, all are nearby.

tripreview.Title: "Not a great place"
tripreview.sentence: Had expectations and visited not a great one.
Needs maintenance.
I think sea food lovers may like.
I am a vegan so i don't know on that part.

tripreview.Title: "The place still feels alive"
tripreview.sentence: Mattancherry is the old part of Kochi.
It was the centre of the universe for the famed spice trade, which put Kochi on the world map.
There is a huge bit of feels in the area, including the Dutch Palace, which to me looked like a Dutch over-statement.
By all standards it is no bigger than a prosperous Kerala matriach's residence.
But the history is a bit wobbly.
Apparently, it was the courtyard of a hindu temple.
The Portugese ransacked the temple and built a palace in the courtyard.
Then something happened (between pages 16 and 26 of history books) and the Dutch took over the palace as the base of their trading operations under the Dutch East India Company.
Long story short, the place now is a museum hosing history of the erstwhile local Kerala kings.
Not much to see.
Move on.
The road ahead in called Jew Street.
No further comment.
At the end of a circular round-about is a Synagogue.
For some reason it is called the Pardesi Synagogue (foreigner's temple), and doesn't have a proper name.

Maybe it was the heat or just my tired bones, I was hallucinating about old, wizened jews and colourful ship-pies haggling all over Jew Street, with piles of silk cloth and sacks of spices and gold kept under temporary awnings, held up by bamboos.
The Indian traders used to ply their trade on the road connecting Fort Kochi to Mattancherry.
All in all this is a great place to soak in a bit of history, let the mind roam free, imagine pirates with exotic birds on their shoulders.
Time your visit so that you don't have to hook up a big mean when you are around.
There is no decent place to eat.
But feast on fresh coconut water.
Have fun.

tripreview.Title: "Life as a Local."
tripreview.sentence: Narrow street, busy shops and everything you can think of as old school, you will find here.
From Jews Head caps, to fine tapestry, to antique clocks, you will find at all.
Or, You can simply stroll the spice market.

tripreview.Title: "Shop, shop, shop"
tripreview.sentence: Great place to shop some handicraft stuff.
Jewish synagogue is must visit.
Be ready to do some last moment shopping as you won't be able to resist yourself.

tripreview.sentence: The hustle bustle here gives one a sense of rush and calm at the same time.

Shopping also was okay - but too much junk and too little authentic stuff.
The synagogue visit was disappointing.

tripreview.Title: "INTERESTING HISTORICAL PLACE IN KOCHI"
tripreview.sentence: Mattancherry is part of Ernakulam district in Kerala and is a touristy destination.
There is a boat jetty where boats go to Ernakulam, Fort Kochi and Willingdon island.
There are bazaars to buy spices, tea and antiques.
It is also famous for Jew town where ancient jews started their trading.
The Jew Palace and the Jew Synagogue are famous landmarks there.

tripreview.Title: "Oldest European Settlement"
tripreview.sentence: The landmark sites are well preserved and present some wonderful pictures of the rich and mixed colonial history of the bygone era even today.

tripreview.Title: "Fort Kochi and Mattancherry-The Oldest European Settlement in India"
tripreview.sentence: Fort Kochi and Mattancherry are the apt destinations if you love to make a walk through the colonial history of India.
A visit to these places will teach you a lot about the rich past of the Jews, the Dutch, the Portuguese and the English community and their culture prevailed in the area.
Fortunately, all these landmark sites are well preserved and present some wonderful pictures of the rich and mixed colonial history of the bygone era even today.
I've done a couple of trips this historic town and enjoyed each of my trips very much.
You can read my total experience there on the following link: http://sunilkunnoth2012.
hubpages.
com/hub/Fort-Kochi-Mattancherry-Kerala-The-Oldest-European-Settlement-In-India Please do visit and enjoy yourself a different experience.

tripreview.sentence: The Dutch Palace, Jain Temple and Pardesi Synagogue are in this area of Cochi.

The painted murals in the Dutch Palace were among the most amazing sites in Cochi.

tripreview.sentence: It s an assault on the senses but worth it.

When I refused to show him my pictures, he gave me a chinese burn twist to my wrist to force me.
Sure enough, nothing there and incensed, I left.
Found an amazing cafe at the top end of Cemetery Rd on the left called Ganeshi and had a plain dosa or masala dosa with mango lassi.

Jain Temple and lots of go downs to visit , take care not to get lost.

The sellers in the shops were not as pushy this year but then it was a lot quieter as well and they would just let you have a look rather than pouncing on you from all directions.
Some great bargains to be had in the area if you are prepared to be patient, be fair and haggle.
Plenty of restaurants in the locale for food or drinks.
Definitely recommended for a wander though but be warned so many nice things to tug at your wallet around here too!

tripreview.Title: "An amazing walk down the streets of Mattanchery"
tripreview.sentence: Walk by the streets of Mattanchery and experience yourself the uniqueness of the area which cannot be experienced from any where else in town.

tripreview.Title: "Old, eclectic neighbourhood"
tripreview.sentence: It s almost impossible not to find something for every taste here.

Starting with the architecture of the different churches, palaces, temples, mosques, old houses, spice markets, and ending up with the shopping streets and the vast array of restaurants , there is something for everyone.
Make sure you explore the small alleys, there are surprises at every corner , old cemeteries, local and authentic restaurants and, everywhere, the nice locals.

Very touristy.
In the end, the Dutch Palace was the highlight.
Overwhelming in historical information, the museum was reasonably priced with a modest entrance fee.
Luckily we got in and out before the throngs of school kids arrived.
No need to get a rickshaw guide for all of these sights.
Just get some exercise and walk if you are decent shape.
We were advised to walk around the tip of the island, and not venture into the middle with the narrow streets and traffic.
We ignore the advise, but I can see why locals would advise against taking the seemingly direct route.

Walls.

tripreview.Title: "An excellent place to visit. A Must See Place"
tripreview.sentence: Mattancherry, the western part of the corporation of Cochin, was once a bustling centre of trade, particularly in spices.
Invasions from across the sea was frequent and the invaders left indelible marks on the landscape, culture, art and social history of the place.
Mattancherry welcomed every migrant community that came to her with warmth and provided them with ample opportunities to flourish.
Thanks to the benevolence of the erstwhile kings of Cochin, many a community like that of Jews, Konkanis, Gujaratis, Jains and Marathis made the place their home.
Even today, Mattancherry has people of different tongues and ethnic identities.
Churches, agraharams, mosques and a synagogue co-exist in the area, along with the buildings of the colonial era, pointing to a vibrant past and a harmonious present.
Like in any other place in Kerala, people of various religious communities like Hindus, Muslims, Latin Christians and Syrian Christians co-exist in Mattancherry.
Migrant communities such as Jews, Konkanis and Kutchi Muslims, though lesser in number, have also lived in Mattancherry for generations.
These communities enhance the cosmopolitan ambience of Mattancherry.
The synagogue is open every day except Fridays, Saturdays and Jewish holidays.
Timings: forenoon - 10 am to 12 noon; afternoon - 3 pm to 5 pm.
Visitors are expected to enter the synagogue barefoot.

tripreview.Title: "Nice and quite village"
tripreview.sentence: It was a real nice experience visiting Mattancherry - Dutch Palace, Jew Town, Syngouge were quite nice.
The ongoing Kochi Biennale was an added attraction.
The doves at the Jain Temple was an amazing watch.
Lunch at Annapurna Sweets and Restaurant was very good, nice Gujarati Thaali served there.

tripreview.Title: "Mattancherry"
tripreview.sentence: Tourist trap near Kochi main town.
Plenty of shops selling overpriced "Indian" type souvenirs all very similar with the usual touts attempting to lure you inside.
Watch the drivers who take you to shops - they're all on commission.
However worth a walk in the cool of the evening to soak up the atmosphere and see the locals at play.

tripreview.Title: "Dutch palace and more!"
tripreview.sentence: This is a nice place to visit.
I like to go there by walk through spice market.
You can smell all kinds of spices there while walking.
Life of people working there is also amazing.
Dutch palace is nice.
Streets and people living here are worth the visit.

tripreview.Title: "Historic place"
tripreview.sentence: Mattenchery Dutch Palace Museum is a miss-it-not place since we can have a look at the old history of Kochi Rajas; their costumes, the things they used, the coins and stamps they used for trading, etc.

tripreview.Title: "Crowded but interesting"
tripreview.sentence: The winding streets had interesting things on display.
Looked as if the place was frozen in time.
Shops outside the Dutch Palace has nice stuff but very overpriced.
Good experience.

tripreview.Title: "Crowded part of the old city"
tripreview.sentence: This historical part of the old city of Cochin is today basically a crowded marketplace.
The famous Kochi synagogue is in this area Best accessed by boat from the Ernakulam mainland, the tourism potential of this area has been very much underutilized.

tripreview.Title: "Jews Synagong"
tripreview.sentence: This place is famous for the Jewish Synagong built in 1538 by the Dutch.

the area is supposed to house Jews and the shops outside the synagong is supposed to belong to them and that place is famous for items of that era, but sadly we found lots of Kashmiri shops and there were just a handful of antique shops which were so very costly, otherwise well maintained area.

tripreview.Title: "Visit Mattacherry Palace"
tripreview.sentence: Whenever you go to Mattancherry, dont forget to visit Mattacherry Palace .
Simple and plain from exterior, this palace features rooms with intrinsically carved ceilings and murals.

tripreview.Title: "a visit to historical place"
tripreview.sentence: Shops in this part of town are full on hard sell, touts outside were actually quite a pain in the rear.
Best advice say no and keep walking (if you don't want to go inside) getting involved in polite conversation is not appreciated too much unless you actually go in.
Pricing down this neck of the woods is pretty horrendous too, rip off central if you are not careful.
That said there are some remarkable shops down here that operate fixed pricing where the price is more than reasonable!
So well worth looking around.

If you're not comfortable with haggling then you are going to get ripped off Spice shops in this part of town do not reduce their prices too much with haggling making it exceptionally bad value for money.
Really worth looking around for your spice requirements along Bazaar Rd or popping over to Ernakulam's Bazaar area.

tripreview.Title: "Fascinating place"
tripreview.sentence: The Dutch Palace was actually built by the Portuguese as a present for the local Rajah but was remodelled by the Dutch.
It has interesting memorabilia from the old royal house but the main reason for going are the murals telling the story of the Ramayama.

tripreview.Title: "Mattancherry-Ancient art center"
tripreview.sentence: It is about 9 km from Ernakulam town.
There are frequent bus and boat services to Mattancherry from Ernakulam town.
The boats start from Main Boat Jetty near Subash Park at Ernakulam.
Mattancherry is also home to the Paradesi Synagogue (India's oldest functioning synagogue), the history of coming of Jew shown here, Mattancherry Palace (Dutch Palace).
The museum hosts various paintings and murals.
The history of Kerla is also shown here.
There is a Bazaar (Market) where we buy different spices and articles used interior decorations.
There are lot of art shops in the market.
